<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
0625/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 299, 317]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 220, 618]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 730, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 544, 91]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows a trolley travelling down a ramp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 313, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
The trolley has a piece of paper tape attached to it. The tape passes through a machine which makes a dot on the tape every 0.02 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 455, 378]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 498, 897, 516]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 406, 910, 425]]<|/det|>
A ball falls over the edge of the cliff. The mass of the ball is \(160 \text{g}\). The height of the cliff is \(115 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 437, 146, 457]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 256, 798, 275]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows a model car travelling at constant speed on a flat circular track.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 607, 920, 641]]<|/det|>
The speed of the car is \(0.30 \text{m/s}\). In one complete revolution around the track, the car travels \(3.9 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 654, 183, 672]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 654, 850, 672]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 808, 920, 826]]<|/det|>
<form>time = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 181, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, draw and label with the letter F an arrow to show the resultant force acting on the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 117, 180, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 116, 920, 151]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 796, 920, 831]]<|/det|>
The volume of gas in the cylinder is \(3400 \text{cm}^3\). The pressure of the gas in the cylinder is \(0.90 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 500, 150]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 920, 320]]<|/det|>

<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 883, 87]]<|/det|>
Electrical power is produced in a power station by an alternating current (a.c.) generator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 85, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The output of the generator has a voltage of \(22 000 \text{V}\). The electrical power is transmitted at a voltage of \(400 000 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 858, 152]]<|/det|>
Explain why electrical power is transmitted at a voltage of \(400 000 \text{V}\) and not \(22 000 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 320, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 146, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 447, 368]]<|/det|>
A computer contains a transformer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
The input voltage to the transformer is \(240 \text{V}\). The output voltage from the transformer is \(20 \text{V}\) and the output current is \(2.3 \text{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 490, 445]]<|/det|>
